1.content:
Hi. My name's JJ Juspeczyk, and this is my story.

It was the summer I turned 17 when it happened. I lived with my parents, Frank and Amelia; my 14-year-old brother, Frank, Jr.; and my baby sister, Grace, who was 3. Dad was a police detective, and Mom was an architect who worked from home.

Since it was summer, I was working on my podcast, The J Files. On it, I examined mysteries old and new that had the authorities stumped.

Want to know more about me? Well, I was moderately athletic, with light brown hair and seafoam green eyes. Of course, if you were to look at me now, you'd never suspect that I looked like that.

Matter of fact, if you were to look at me now, you wouldn't even suspect you were looking at me.

******************************


When people hear that my podcast is about mysteries, sometimes they assume that I'm doing tons of legwork, following up on leads, or even mixing it up with the bad guys in person. But I don't do that. Even today, I prefer to keep a low profile.

In fact, my strategy is completely straightforward: I ask people questions, and they tell me things. Then, I put those things out there on my podcast, and my listeners give the authorities any tips they might have. It's worked pretty well: By the time my life changed, three of the cases I'd spotlighted were officially closed. Officially, the police chalked it up to good police work and cooperation from the public. Unofficially, Dad has thanked me three times.

My last podcast before the big It happened dealt with a mystery that was close to home, as I told my listeners: Joanna Binkley, my great-great-aunt on my mother's side, had vanished without a trace, back when she was about my age. Everybody looked for her, but nobody could figure out where she went, or who might have gone with her. There was even a spooky bit, which sold me on making it an episode of The J Files, and which I made sure to pass along to my listeners: Several family members said that they had heard her voice after she disappeared. However, when they looked, she wasn't there.

After my friend, Izzy, got done editing what I'd recorded, I uploaded it. Then, we blew off some steam at the mall, I had supper and hung out with my family, and I went upstairs to bed.

And that was the last anyone saw of me.

******************************


The next morning, I took a shower. Everything started out normal. The only thing that was different was that, once or twice, I thought I saw the shower head while I had my eyes closed. But neither time lasted for more than a second or two. I chalked it up to a vivid imagination, and finished my shower.

Wrapping myself in a towel, I began brushing my teeth. That's when it happened.

One second, I was brushing my teeth. The next, my toothbrush was there, the toothpaste on my teeth was there, and the towel was there.

I, however, had disappeared, right before my eyes.

I closed my eyes.

Not only didn't I reappear, but closing my eyes had no effect at all on what I was seeing. I could see through my eyelids. I could see through me.

I was invisible.

I think I was justified in screaming at the top of my lungs.
1.title: How It Began

choices: My Doctor Makes a House Call
11.content:
The next voice I heard was Mom's. "JJ?" she asked, knocking on the bathroom door. "Did you scream?"

I was glad it was Mom. I didn't want Frankie to see me in nothing but a towel, even invisible. "Yes." I opened the door.

It took Mom a minute to process what she was looking at, not that I blamed her. "Jessica? Are you... there?"

"I'm here," I said, nodding, though she couldn't tell. "I don't know how it happened, but... "

After a minute or two, Mom said, "Finish what you're doing and get dressed. Maybe we can figure something out."

Just act normal. Okay. That gave me something to do. After the shock, I had no idea how to react. I had no frame of reference.

Pregnant? I knew girls my age who got pregnant, so I knew how I would feel if it was me.

Cancer? We'd lost a neighbor to cancer, so I knew how I'd feel about that.

But who the hell turns invisible?

Getting dressed was a little bit difficult. You get so used to seeing your own body that, when you're invisible, it takes a couple tries to get it right. Finally, though, I stood fully dressed in front of my mirror.

And then I watched as my clothes disappeared. "Shit."

With no alternative, I went downstairs. This took longer, too, without being able to see my feet.

Mom and Dad were talking at the breakfast nook, about me. "What are we supposed to do about this?" Dad asked.

"I don't know," Mom replied. "Maybe, when she gets down here, we can figure something out."

"I'm here."

Mom and Dad both jumped. "You startled us," Mom said. "Why didn't you get dressed?"

"I am dressed. My clothes just turned invisible, too."

Frankie and Grace came downstairs. "What's going on?" Frankie asked.

"Sit down," I said, "it's a long story."
11.title: Mom Reaches Me First

111.content:
I still don't know how, but Mom managed to talk Dr. Garrett into coming to the house. "Thank you for coming, Doctor," Mom said as she let Dr. Garrett inside.

"You're welcome," she replied, "though I can't imagine why JJ couldn't just come in. So, where is she?"

"Right here," I said.

Dr. Garrett looked around. "Where are you hiding, JJ? And how did you do that with your voice?"

I picked up her medical bag. "I'm right here. The problem is, nobody can see me. Not even me."

******************************


There wasn't a lot Dr. Garrett could do in the way of examining me. She could shine a light in my eyes (which was so much worse, now that closing my eyes and covering them with my hand had no effect), but it told her nothing. She checked my ears (invisible) and my throat (ditto). About the only tests she could run were listening to my heart and lungs, and taking my blood pressure. She had as much trouble with this as I had getting dressed. "Can you tell us anything, Doctor?" Dad asked.

"Well, JJ's blood pressure is elevated," she replied, "though that might just be stress. Other than that, all I can say is that she seems to be healthy, as much as I can tell."

"I'm a little relieved," I said. "I was afraid I'd be poked and prodded, trying to find out why I'm invisible."

"I wouldn't know where to start," Dr. Garrett said. "I can't take a blood sample without knowing by sight where your blood vessels are."

After Dr. Garrett left, I started thinking about what was next. My friends, Izzy and Mina, would be coming over sooner or later. So would my boyfriend, Nick. How would they react when they saw me, or didn't see me?
111.title: My Doctor Makes a House Call

1111.content:
I got the answer to my first question fifteen minutes after Dad left, when Izzy and Mina came by.

Izzy Kessler, as you will recall, was my number one assistant on The J Files, helping me with editing and content. Mina Johnson didn't help with the podcast, but she was my oldest friend. We grew up together. She learned the fastest how to pronounce Juspeczyk (it's "yoos-PET-chick"), which certainly got her points from Dad.

"Hey, Mrs. Juspeczyk," Mina said. "Is JJ busy? We were hoping to get some shopping done."

"No, she isn't busy, Mina," Mom said. "But I don't know if she feels like going anywhere."

"I can fix that," Izzy said. She was carrying a metal water bottle: she had had a kidney transplant, and needed to stay hydrated. At that moment, she tossed her bottle aside...

... right into my shin. "Ouch."

"Sorry, JJ," Izzy said, turning in my direction. Then, she turned back where she was going, and made it three steps before she stopped.

She turned to look in my direction. "JJ?"

Mina had seen the whole thing. She came as close as she dared. "JJ? Are you... there?"

"What's left of me," I said.

Which caused both of them to freak out, a condition which, in their cases, caused flailing of limbs. When they hit me, they would apologize, then they'd remember why they hit me, which caused them to freak out again. Repeat.

Finally, they calmed down enough to start asking questions. Unfortunately, most of these were the same questions I'd been dealing with all morning, so there wasn't much new information.

"You know what I know," I said. "I'm the only one who's ever turned invisible, and I don't know why."

"Are you, though?" Izzy asked. "Are you the only one?"

"What do you mean, Izzy?" Mom asked.

"The podcast," Izzy replied. "Your great-great-aunt, the one who disappeared? What was that really spooky bit?"

"They thought they heard her," Mom said, "but, when they looked, she wasn't there."

"They heard her," Izzy said, "they looked. Well, I hear you, JJ, but, when I look,... " She gestured at the indentation in the couch cushion, the only visual indication that I was present.

Mom clutched Frankie and Grace to her. "My babies."

"I'm sure they're fine, Mom," I said. "If Izzy is right, I'm the first in four generations this has happened to."

And I was pretty sure that Izzy was right.

I mean, maybe it was wishful thinking, but it fit the facts as well as anything had. And it gave me a frame of reference for what had happened to me: I was invisible because it ran in Mom's family.

"I'm sorry," Mom said.

"You couldn't have known," I replied.
1111.title: Izzy and Mina

11111.content:
That afternoon, we were sitting around, beginning to calm down, when there came a knock on the door. "JJ?" called Nick's voice. "You okay? You weren't there when I got in."

I had forgotten that I was supposed to meet Nick when he got back from baseball camp. What can I say? It slipped my mind sometime after I became invisible.

Izzy let him in. "Sorry JJ couldn't make it, Nick. Something... happened."

"Is she okay? What happened?"

"It's... kind of hard to explain."

"What? Is she sick? Is she hurt? What's going on?"

"I'm not hurt, Nick," I said. "But... there is something wrong with me."

"JJ? Where are you?"

I touched him. "I'm right here, Nick. You just can't see me. Nobody can."

Nick Connors was the star of the school baseball team. We'd been going together, off and on, for the past two years. Our relationship had had its hiccups in the past, and we thought it was strong enough for anything. But was it strong enough to deal with this?

I told him everything that had happened since morning. "We're not sure how it happened. All I know is, I seem to be stuck like this." I touched Nick again. "Nick,... I'll understand if... if you want to... "

"If I want to what?"

"Well,... you didn't exactly sign on for this sort of thing."

"Well,... let's give it a try."

"Really?"

"JJ, I... I love you. I want us to work out. I... I'm willing to give it a shot, if you are." He paused. "Where are your lips?"

I showed him by kissing him.

When I stopped, Nick said, "Looks like you're going to have to start taking the initiative in this relationship."

"And what do you think of that?"

"I could get used to it."

I kissed him again.
11111.title: Nick Comes to See Me

111111.content:
I got a surprise the next morning, after taking my shower. The water clung to me as I got out, you see, so that I looked like a me-shaped bubble. Of course, once I dried myself, I went back to being invisible.

After getting dressed, and watching my clothes turn invisible as soon as they were on, I went downstairs, knocking as I went. Dad was sitting at the table, so I kissed him on the head. "Morning, Daddy."

"Good morning, JJ," he replied. "How'd you sleep?"

"I had to unplug my alarm clock," I answered. "It lights up a room more than you think."

"Was that you knocking a minute ago?" Mom asked.

"Yeah. I wanted to let you know I was coming."

"Sounds like we weren't the only ones thinking about this," she said to Dad.

"What have you been thinking?"

"Homeschooling. I want to homeschool you."

"Beats being marked as absent in every class. And I won't need to worry about how raising my hand is going to work."

"Precisely. Now, speaking of attendance, I'm not going to have to worry about you slipping out while I'm trying to teach you, am I? Because I'm not afraid of getting creative to make sure you're where I want you."

"I'll be good," I promised.

******************************


Later that morning, Izzy and Mina came by. "Can JJ come out?" Izzy asked.

"There's a sentence I haven't heard for a while," Mom said. "Why do you ask?"

"Well," Mina said, "we thought, maybe she'd like to see a movie?"

"I'd love to see a movie," I replied.
111111.title: The Next Morning

1111111.content:
So you're probably thinking, How does someone who's invisible go to the movies?

Much the same way you do, as it turns out.

See, the people who sell tickets and concessions don't really care how people spend their money. If two girls want to buy three tickets, that's their business. Likewise, if those same two girls want to buy enough popcorn and sodas for three people, that's also their business. And, if those two girls choose to sit with one empty seat between them, whose business is that? You're catching on.

The movie we went to see was Expecting the Unexpected, a drama about a teenage girl who finds herself pregnant, even though she's never had sex. Speaking as someone who has had a bizarre experience, that would definitely be one for the books, or at least The J Files.

******************************


On the way back home, we had to stop at a gas station, so I could use the bathroom. Now, conducting my business on a gas station toilet would never be my first choice, but I couldn't hold it until we got home, and I couldn't have gone at the movies: after all, the only thing worse than having someone sit on you in a movie theater would be having someone sit on you in the restroom. Mina went with me, to give me cover, and she kept her back turned to the toilet as I did what had to be done.

When we got back to the car, Mina quipped, "You should find out what this place charges for repairs. The door to the back seat keeps opening and closing by itself."

As we got underway, Izzy asked, "JJ, can I ask a personal question?"

"Let's hear it."

"When you... go,... what happens to the... I mean, is it... ?"

I interrupted her. "While it's still inside me, it's invisible. Once it comes out, it turns visible. Thanks for going with me, Mina. You gave me something to look at besides that."
1111111.title: At the Movies

choices: A note with a reply appears.
11111111.content:
Upon returning home, I momentarily forgot to make noises walking in, and found Mom and Dad sitting at the dinning room table, talking. Both seemed very worried. "What could it mean?" Whispering, Mom asked.

"It could mean anything." Sighing, Dad said. "Only, it's obviously meant for JJ."

"What is meant for me?" Curious, I asked. Mom and Dad both jumped, to which I immediately added, "Sorry, I forgot to announce myself."

"It seems you are not the only invisible person around here." Surprising me, Dad said. "A note appeared out of thin air, and landed onto the table between your mother and I."

"At first, we thought it was you leaving a note, and we feared you had somehow lost your voice." Worried, Mom added. "Only upon reading it..."

Dad held out the note for me to take, it was in cursive and it read:

I fear we share a common problem.


"The handwriting suggests it was a teenage girl." Serious, Dad said. "We searched the house as best we could, but found no evidence of forced entry."

"How do you determine if an invisible person got in?" worried, I asked.

Dad sighed. "Good question. A better question is, how did she know about you?"

"It would seem this mystery just got deeper." Wincing, I said.

After a thought, Mom said, "I know this is grasping at straws, but... try writing a note back, and leave it here for this person to find."

"It's worth a shot." Shrugging, I said.

I then picked up a notebook from the counter and wrote:

Who are you, how do I reach you?


After writing the note, I placed it onto the table. Within seconds, the note vanished!

For the first time since this had happened, I was looking around for someone who 'wasn't there'...
11111111.title: At Home, a cryptic clue.

111111111.content:
We all jumped when a second note appeared from nowhere and floated down onto the table. I picked it up and read it out loud. "Jo Jo Juspeczyk... searching for clues... my great-great-uncle disappeared at my age... guess it's our turn now... tried to talk, no one hears me here... just notes for now."

"Jo Jo..." Surprised, Mom asked.

"You know her?" Curious, I asked.

Mom shook her head. "It's just one of the many names I had considered before you were born." Softly, she explained. "I finally settled on simply JJ."

"So this Jo Jo may be an alternate version of you." Raising an eyebrow, Dad said. "Interesting..."

"You mean like a parallel world?" Taken aback, I asked. "Is that even possible?"

"I might have thought not," Mom said. "But I thought the same thing about invisibility, until yesterday."

"We are just beginning to understand the world around us." Serious, Dad said. "Every day, someone discovers something new... anything is possible."

Mom left the room for a moment then returned with two notebooks. "Jo Jo, if you can hear me, this book is for you, and the other is for JJ." Calmly, she said. "Please, talk to each other."

She then placed the two notebooks onto the table. I pulled one chair and sat down. It was a surprise to all when an empty chair moved on its own. Jo Jo was in the room. I wrote down:

How did you get here?

The response was, I do not know. I thought I was going home when I saw you.

Surprised, I wrote, How can you see me?

The response was, Close your eyes.

Uncertain, I closed my eyes and jumped upon seeing a mirror image of myself sitting in a chair opposite of me! Jo Jo smiled sadly. before writing, I need your help, JJ Juspeczyk, to get back home.

I sighed then wrote, Why can't I see you with my eyes open?

Jo Jo sighed then wrote, I do not know. Maybe invisibility just works that way.

Mom and Dad, who were reading our notes back and forth, turned to each other, curious. They closed their eyes before sighing, opening them again. "I guess it only works while you are invisible." Disappointed, Mom said.

"There has to be a way to make them visible." Serious, Dad said. "Anything they are holding or wearing vanishes, so I'm guessing it's some form of aura surrounding them."

Jo Jo wrote, My mom is a police detective, she believes that may be the case too.

"Okay, we will need to start with what you both have figured out so far." Serious, Dad said. "Maybe together, we can find a few clues and solve this mystery."

Jo Jo and I both sighed, then began writing down everything we had discovered thus far since we had become invisible.
111111111.title: A note with a reply appears.

1111111111.content:
I compiled my list:

1) Yesterday morning, I became invisible. I think it's related to my great-great-aunt's disappearance.
2) Anything I wear or carry becomes invisible until I take it off or put it down.
3) Food becomes invisible when I hold it. This means I can eat without grossing out the whole table.
4) When I go to the bathroom, it stays invisible until it's a few inches away from me. This is even less appealing to watch than it sounds.
5) My family has my back.
6) My best friends, Izzy and Mina, are right with me.
7) Nick loves me, and wants to give us a chance.

All in all, I thought, a fairly comprehensive list.

I thought that right up until I saw Jo Jo's list. Apart from different names (presumably alternate versions of people in my life), the list had these items:

8) I can make myself intangible.
9) When I'm intangible, I can see myself. I'm transparent, but I'm there.
10) When I want to, I can move completely silently. Not even a creaky floorboard can give me away.
11) I seem to have traveled to another world.

"How did you figure this out?" I asked.

I tried things, Jo Jo wrote. If I can get back to my world, the bad guys will fear The J Files like never before.

"You do The J Files too?" I asked. "But why would criminals be afraid of you, instead of being afraid of your listeners telling the authorities what they know?"

That's not what I do. I investigate crimes, and broadcast the evidence.

"That has to give your parents nightmares," Mom said.

Mom keeps threatening to arrest me. Of course, like this, what are the bad guys going to do to me?

Damn, I thought, my alternate self is badass.
1111111111.title: comparing notes.

choices: Dad asks Jo Jo if she has her cellphone.
Das asks me and Jo Jo to hold hands.
11111111111.content:
After a thought, Dad said, "I have an idea..."

Dad left the room and walked down the stairs to the basement. I could hear him rummaging around for something, before his heavy footfalls announced his return. He was carrying a bulky reel-to-reel that looked like a miniature version of an old fashioned computer from the nineteen fifties. "What on Earth is that, dad?" Curious, I asked.

"This is a modified reel-to-reel recorder that can speed up or slow down a person's voice in real time, so I can better understand what a person is saying during an interview." Calmly, Dad replied. "Those who are excitable tend to talk very fast. Also, there are those who talk very slow for various reasons, and this speeds it up into normal speech."

Jo Jo wrote, My mom has something similar.

Dad set up the recorder, then placed the microphone in front of where Jo Jo was sitting, unseen. He then instructed Jo Jo to say 'hello' again and again as he adjusted the dials. At first, nothing seemed to happen but everyone froze when we heard a voice similar to my own say, "Hello."

"We have a winner at 15,000 Hz." Smiling, Dad said. "It's just beyond the normal hearing range of the average human."

"So, I'm talking in such a high pitch, no one can hear me?" Worry in her voice, Jo Jo asked.

"I'm guessing that Jo Jo has not fully crossed over into this world." Serious, dad explained. "She is talking through the barrier, which is causing her voice to be too high-pitched for anyone to pick up, other than animals, who have more acute hearing."

"Well, at least we can talk instead of writing everything down." Calmly, Mom said.

"That's a relief." sighing, Jo Jo said. "I was starting to get cramps from all the writing."

"Likewise." Sighing, I replied. "How do you make yourself intangible?"

With my eyes closed, I could see Jo Jo shrug. "I was thinking about calm waters, a relaxation technique, and it happened..."

I drew a cleansing breath then visualized an open beach near the ocean, my own relaxation technique. As I did, I heard gasps in the room. Opening my eyes, I saw that I could see an outline of myself! I was ghostlike, but visible! Only, just as it had happened, I vanished again. I closed my eyes and turned to Jo Jo, who sadly shook her head.

"I figured out that I can make myself sort of visible for a short time too." Softly, she said. "Only it's like flexing a rarely used muscle, it tires me out very quickly and leads to cramps later."

I winced, feeling a dull ache falling over my body. "I see what you mean..."

"There has to be a way to see or detect both of you." Serious, Dad said. "Perhaps a specific scent, or some form of makeup..."

"I tried makeup." Serious, Jo Jo said. "It vanishes the second it is on my face." She sighed. "As for a specific scent, it becomes useless once one becomes used to it."

"There has to be a way." Serious, Dad repeated.

"I only became sort of visible with water on me after a shower." Sighing, I said.

Dad paused then said... "This might take some time to figure out..."

"My dad never quits on a case that is handed to him." Looking at Jo Jo, I said.

Jo Jo smiled. "Neither does my mom."

Suddenly, Dad said, "It might work..."

"What might work?" Curious, Jo Jo asked.
11111111111.title: Continue

111111111112.content:
"Let's see what happens," Dad said, "when the two of you hold hands."

"How will that help?" I asked.

"It might short-circuit whatever's making you invisible, and shock you back to visibility."

Through closed eyes, I saw Jo Jo shrug. "Worth a shot."

I nodded. "Here goes nothing."

With our eyes closed, Jo Jo and I reached for each other. I just felt our hands touch,...

ZAP!


I found myself lying on the floor, wondering what in the world just happened.

I rubbed my eyes, and it took me a few seconds to notice it:

I could see my hand.

It was transparent, not completely visible, but I could still see it better than I'd seen it since yesterday morning. Maybe Dad was on to something.

Except, when I looked around, he wasn't there.

Neither was Mom.

I called out for them. Or, rather, I tried to. I couldn't hear my voice.

Didn't Jo Jo say that she suddenly couldn't speak when she wound up in our universe?

I heard running footsteps approaching the room I was in. My heart leapt when I saw Mom and Dad run in.

It came crashing down, however, when the person I thought was Dad said, "Jo Jo? Is that you?"
111111111112.title: Das asks me and Jo Jo to hold hands.

choices: Jo Jo is questioned by dad.
1111111111121.content:
I groaned, realizing that I was in Jo Jo's universe, and looked around for a notebook and pen. Fortunately, there was one readily available. Jo's dad gripped his wife's shoulder as the notebook vanished from a counter. I quickly wrote a note and left it on the same table Jo Jo and I were sitting at in my own universe...

*I'm JJ. Jo Jo is in my world. You need your recorder. 15,000 HZ.*

Upon reading it, Jo's mother, Amelia, rushed up the stairs. I could only assume she was running up the attic where I presumed she stored the recorder. Presently, she came down with it, and set up the microphone before turning the dial to 15,000 Hz. "Talk to us, err, JJ." Firmly but kindly, she said. "What happened?"

I sat down in a chair near the microphone and spoke. I was relieved to hear my own voice come through the speaker. "My name is JJ Juspeczyk. Like your daughter, I was working on a case for my J Files, only I was searching for my lost great great aunt."

"I take it you, too, found yourself invisible." Sighing, the father, Frank said.

"Actually, after what had just happened, I theorize that Jo Jo and I are linked, trapped together between our two worlds." To Frank and Amelia's surprise, I said. "Dad suggested we hold hands to try to short circuit what had happened to us and make us both visible."

Amelia sighed, shaking her head. "Only instead, it swapped you two."

I nodded, though they could not see me. "That would appear to be the case, ma'am."

"Just call me Amelia." With a wave of her hand, Amelia said. "I want you to tell me everything that had happened since you became invisible. You would be surprised how something seemingly insignificant could be a vital clue."

"You sound like my father." sighing, I said.

"If your father is anything like me, he would be doing the same thing in his world." firmly, Amelia replied. "Now then, let us get started..."
1111111111121.title: The Wrong World

11111111111211.content:
"For a start," Amelia said, "when did you first turn invisible?"

"It was yesterday morning. I think I had some flashes of invisibility while I was in the shower, because I remember seeing the shower head with my eyes closed a couple of times. But it stuck while I was brushing my teeth."

Amelia nodded. "Jo Jo had the same experience. What came next?"

"I screamed. My mom came and saw where I should have been. She told me to get dressed. I did, but my clothes turned invisible on me."

She nodded again. "Then what?"

"Mom talked my doctor into making a house call. She said I seemed to be healthy. You know, apart from nobody being able to see me. And she promised not to tell anybody about me."

"Okay. And then?"

"My friends, Izzy and Mina, came over. They freaked out when they first realized I was invisible, but they've been supportive. The same with my boyfriend, Nick. I mean, he actually used the L-word, in front of my family, and he wants to give us a chance."

"Anything else?"

"Today, I went to the movies with Izzy and Mina. Then I came home, and found out that your daughter, Jo Jo, somehow wound up in my universe. And here we are."

"You haven't been exploring your powers?"

"No, ma'am. To me, being invisible was - is - something I have to deal with. I was surprised when Jo Jo told me there were other things connected to this."

"Fascinating," Amelia said. "Your voice sounds like my daughter's, but you and she have very different personalities."

"But what does it mean?" asked Jo Jo's dad, who, I guess, was Frank.

"There's some other connection," Amelia replied. "You mentioned you, too, have a podcast called The J Files. What do you do with it?"

"I tell my listeners about mysteries that the authorities haven't been able to solve, and hope that they can come up with the missing pieces. My last one was about an ancestor of mine, who disappeared when she was my age. Izzy and I think it might be connected to my invisibility."

"Okay, let's take a look at that. Tell me about this missing woman."

"She's my great-great-aunt, Joanna Binkley."

Amelia's jaw dropped.

"What did I say?"

"Joanna Binkley is my grandmother's name."

Every now and then, Dad talks about a feeling he gets when he's absolutely certain he's on the right track. He's never been able to describe it, and I cant, either, but I think I got it right then and there. "Jo Jo said her great-great-uncle went missing, at the same age. What's his name?"

"Michael Juspeczyk," Frank said.

"Great-Grandpa," I replied. The game, I thought, is well and truly afoot.
11111111111211.title: I am questioned by Amelia

choices: How My Great-Great-Aunt Became Jo Jo's Great-Grandma
111111111112111.content:
Amelia picked up her phone and dialed. "Grandma? It's Amelia. It's kind of hard to explain, but there's someone here who wants to see you, and I think that you'll want to meet her. Alright. Talk to you as soon as you get here. Love you. 'Bye."

She hung up. "She doesn't live too far from here. You won't have long to wait."

"Maybe Jo Jo's notes will help her," Frank suggested.

"Good idea. I'll go get it." With that, Amelia went upstairs.

She came back with a book that looked like my diary. "Sorry, it's locked," she said. "We may need to break the lock."

I dug out my keys, which included the key that unlocked my diary. Trying it out, I was rewarded with a click, and the lock opened.

Before I could read my double's notes, the solution to another mystery entered the house. "I'm here, Amelia," Joanna said. She looked so much like Mom. "Now, who did you want me to meet?"

"Joanna Binkley," I began, "my name is JJ Juspeczyk. I'm here from another universe. In my world, you disappeared at the age of 17. Now, I've become invisible, and I've somehow been thrown into this universe. I suspect you can tell me something about what's going on."

Joanna sat down. "I haven't heard a story like that since... since it happened to me."
111111111112111.title: Meeting Joanna Binkley

1111111111121111.content:
I took up the notebook and pen, more out of habit. "How did it happen?"

Joanna sighed. "Like you, I was an investigator." Calmly, she began. "Also, like you, I had parents who would tell me to stop my silly hobby and settle down with a nice man."

"Not really," I replied. "My folks are more supportive than your parents were. Different attitudes with different generations and all. But go on."

"Well, my greatest mystery came to me in a state of depression." With a slight frown, Joanna continued. "A simple question; is this all that I am, is there nothing more?" She sighed. "I began to look into various 'what ifs', such as making one decision over another, and, well... I ended up studying parallel worlds."

"I thought that was science fiction," I said. I winced as soon as I said it. After all, I was in a parallel world, wasn't I?

"So did I." Ruefully, Joanna replied. "I began to fantasize over meeting my true love in a parallel universe, a grand adventure, if you will." She giggled. "Little did I know that by doing so, it actually happened, only because someone was doing the same in this universe."

"So when I began searching for you..." Stunned, I began.

Joanna nodded. "Jo Jo began searching for her great, great uncle." Softly, she said. "You and Jo Jo are invisible because you are in between two universes, neither here or there."

"Then how are we..." Surprised, you began.

"Love, my dear." Interrupting me, Joanna said. "I fell in love here, hence I became visible. A new resident of this universe."

"Then I'll become visible again?" Hopeful, I asked.

Joanna shook her head. "You also have a fast friendship with Jo Jo." Serious, she said. "I'm still an investigator at heart, I can read notes with a glance."

"What can I do?" Worried, I asked.

"You need make a choice or make a balance." Serious, Joanna said. "Forget about me, about Jo Jo, and focus only on your boyfriend, and then you will become visible again; or hold on to me, onto Jo Jo, and become her twin sister in this universe." She sighed. "That is the choice. Now, the balance is to give it all equal attention: then, with time and practice, you can become invisible at will."

"Can you be invisible at will?" Curious, I asked.

Joanna shook her head. 'I made the choice to remain here, in this universe, where I found love."

"Is there any way I can return to my own universe?" Hopeful, I asked.

"Think of your boyfriend." Simply, Joanna replied. "That is how you get back. He is your beacon of light in the darkness."

I closed my eyes and thought about Nick. His loving smile, his protective nature...

Before I knew it, I was back in my own dining room, where I found my great-great-grandfather standing in the room. I moved a chair to sit down, to which Grandpa smiled. "Glad to see you made it back, pumpkin." Softly, he said. "How is your great-great-aunt?"
1111111111121111.title: How My Great-Great-Aunt Became Jo Jo's Grea...

11111111111211111.content:
"She's every bit as healthy as you are, Grandpa," I told him. Turning to Jo Jo, I asked, "Okay if I copy off your notes? I really want to try this stuff."

"Go ahead. How'd you get it open?"

"It uses the same key as my diary."

I copied down everything Jo Jo had learned about the things we can do when we're invisible. I couldn't wait to try them out, now that I knew I could do it. Meeting Jo Jo, and turning invisible, had inspired me to try more things.

When I was finished, I handed the notebook back to Jo Jo. "Grandpa told you everything?"

"All of it. Think I won't see you again?"

"You'll always be a part of me. Take care."

"You, too." I watched, with closed eyes, as Jo Jo closed her eyes and disappeared from my world.

"So," Mom said, "you learned how to come back to our world. Ready to try the other part?"

"Let's do it." I closed my eyes, and focused on my feelings for Nick. The way my lips tingled when he kissed me. How safe I felt when I was wrapped in his arms. My dreams of our bodies as one...

Everything went dark.

When I opened my eyes, I could see just fine again.

Just to confirm it, Mom and Dad spun me to face the mirror. "Hello, gorgeous," I said.
11111111111211111.title: talking to grandpa.

111111111112111111.content:
I went upstairs to my bedroom, closing the door behind me. Now that I had made myself visible, it was time to try to make myself invisible again.

Since thoughts of Nick made me visible again, I decided to try thoughts of Jo Jo. Her daring. Her cunning. Her...

And, just like that, I was invisible again. So far, so good, I thought.

Now, it was time to try to make myself intangible. Jo Jo had said it was relaxation techniques, but that made me transparent, and it was hard. Checking her notes, I saw her mistake: The key to it was to clear your mind. I focused on my breathing, listened to my heartbeat. When I felt ready, I walked toward the closed door, and then went right through it. Awesome sauce. Then, I went back in, and made myself tangible again.

Becoming totally silent was a challenge. For a girl who had twice scared the poop out of my parents by surprising them, it was hard getting into the mindset necessary to cancel all noise. I felt like I was studying a martial art. It was going to take practice.

Time enough for that later. I heard the door open downstairs, and Nick talking to my folks. Now that I knew what to do, becoming visible again was a snap.

I went downstairs and found Nick. The look on his face was priceless.
111111111112111111.title: Trying Things Out

1111111111121111111.content:
"How did you become visible again?" Surprised, Nick asked. "Do-Don't get me wrong, I'm glad you're visible again, but... "

I kissed Nick on the lips, ending his rambling before it could start. "Let's just say, I found my great-great-aunt, and she helped me out, along with her great-granddaughter."

"You solved the case?!" Again surprised, Nick asked. He gave a whistle. "That was fast."

Dad suddenly pulled me aside. "Excuse us a moment, Nick." kindly, he said. 'I just need to have a word with my daughter. It won't take but a minute."

Embarrassed and confused, I followed Dad to the other room where he gave me a look I knew from experience meant business. "What did I do?" Wincing, I asked.

"There has been a string of mysterious robberies in the area." Serious, Dad said. "None of the security cameras caught a thing. Thus, they are calling the suspect the 'ghost thief'."

My eyes went wide, hearing that. "You're thinking that, if people learn of my little run-in with invisibility, they would blame me for the crimes."

Dad nodded. "At the very least, you would be the primary suspect." Serious, he said. "Keep your little adventure to yourself, until I can crack this case."

"Do you suspect me?" Worried, I asked.

Dad shook his head with a slight smile. "I've had a GPS tracker on your cellphone since I bought it for you." To my surprise, he explained. "I checked it. You were nowhere near any of the crime scenes, at any time."

"You've been tracking me?" Taken aback, I asked.

"You are a great detective, but I worry about you taking on a case that could put you in danger." Softly, Dad said. "I am not comfortable unless..."

"All bases are covered." sighing, I finished. "Okay, Daddy..."

"It's more than that, dear." Serious, Dad said. "If these thieves are able to become invisible, and they learn of you, they might see you as an obstacle or a threat." He touched my cheek. "Be careful out there...."

After giving Mom and Dad a quick kiss, I walked out with Nick to go out on our date. "So what was it like, being invisible?" Curious, Nick asked.

"I'm really not allowed to talk about it." Wincing, I replied.

"Why not?" Worried, Nick asked.

Not knowing how to explain it, I just said, "Dad... "

Nick shook his head, smiling slightly. "Overprotective as ever."

I just shrugged, smiling, and Nick pulled me into a one-armed hug as we walked to his car.
1111111111121111111.title: Pre-date warning from dad.

11111111111211111112.content:
I was home by 11:00. Nick was a perfect gentleman, opening my car door for me and walking me to the door. "It was nice seeing you again," he said.

"It was nice to be seen," I replied.

"I'll call you tomorrow."

"I can't wait."

We kissed. "Goodnight."

Inside, Mom asked, "How was your date?"

"Lovely," I replied. "We went to that new Italian restaurant, then we saw a movie."

"What kind of movie?" Dad asked.

"A romantic movie. Love brought me back from invisibility. Love brought me back from another universe. I wanted to see more of love."

After goodnight kisses, I went upstairs to my bedroom.

But I didn't go right to bed. Instead, I called Izzy.

"What's up?" she asked.

"First of all," I said, "I'm visible again."

"You are?! How'd it happen?"

"Long story. But I can tell you, you were right about my great-great-aunt."

"Don't keep me in suspense, girlfriend, gimme the deets!"

"Not over the phone. Call Mina and tell her to meet us at the ice cream shop at 11:00 tomorrow morning."

"Can I at least know what it's about?"

"Another case for The J Files."
11111111111211111112.title: After the date.

111111111112111111121.content:
Anyone who saw the way Izzy and Mina reacted to the sight of me would have assumed that we were good friends who hadn't seen each other in a long time. The truth was, it hadn't been that long, but we weren't sure if anybody would ever see me again.

Once I sat down, Izzy said, "Okay, JJ, let's hear it."

"Well," I replied, "it's a long story." And I told them all about it, from my great-great-aunt to the day before.

"Amazing," Mina said, when I finished. "So now, you can turn it on and off when you want?"

"Mmm-hmm. And I'm going to start using it."

"You said there was a case for The J Files," Izzy said. "What is it?"

"You guys know there's been a string of brazen thefts from museums lately, right?"

"Uh-huh," said Mina.

"How do we get involved?" Izzy asked.

"Because Dad told me about a key detail the police haven't revealed to the public: The stolen items weren't just pilfered, they disappeared. And they have no clue as to how the thieves got in or out."

"So?"

"So, how many people do you know who can get in and out undetected, and who can make things vanish just by holding them?"

"So you're saying... "

"I'm saying it's up to me to find who's responsible for these thefts,... before somebody tries pinning it on me."
111111111112111111121.title: The Meeting

1111111111121111111211.content:
"Well, do we know exactly what has been stolen, and why?" Curious, Izzy asked. "Knowing that much can at least help us find a pattern."

"None of the stolen artwork is really considered super valuable, like a Rembrandt or Picasso." Thoughtful, I replied. "However, they all carry significant value to the people of this town, as they depict key moments in its history."

"That is definitely a pattern." Worried, Mina said. "Only why steal art that has almost no value, other than historical significance to the town, when there were more valuable prizes to be had?"

"Good question." Serious, I said. "All I can come up with is that the thieves are after something hidden in town, that is worth more than what they can steal."

"Maybe... a buried treasure?" Shrugging, Izzy said. "The artwork could be pieces to a map or something."

"That's as good a guess as any." Calmly, I said. "We won't know unless we can determine their next target."

"I doubt it will be the museum." After a thought, Mina said. "Not all of the local artwork got put in the town's two museums. Most of them were sold at auction."

I gasped at that. "Dad bought a few of them!" Startled, I said. "He has them hanging in his den at home!"

"Then that is a potential target." Serious, Izzy said. "Only my dad bought a few, too."

"So did mine." Wincing, Mina said. "I think we all need to be on alert tonight."

I nodded. "Don't try to confront whoever it is." Serious, I said. "We do not know if they are armed. If you see anything vanish, hit the house alarm."

We all agreed to the plan, and I went home to tell Dad what we had figured out. Only he was not impressed. "I told you to stay out of this." Firmly, he said. "I know these thieves are after historic paintings of the town, but why is anyone's guess."

"Maybe I can see them while invisible..." Hoping to help, I said.

"What if they can see you while invisible, and are armed?" Darkly, Dad countered. "Worse, you are getting your friends involved." He sighed. "This is not a chapter of Teen Detectives Magazine, where teenagers have super abilities!"

I teared up, hurt. "I just want to help... and you can't see them when they are invisible. I don't want you to get hurt, either."

"I replaced the artwork with fakes that have GPS trackers hidden in them." Calmly, Dad said. "I'm counting on them taking them."

"I didn't think about that." Impressed, I said.

Dad smiled. "That's why I'm the detective."

That night,...
1111111111121111111211.title: We Make a Plan

11111111111211111112111.content:
As I got ready for bed, I had an idea: What if I used my invisibility, not to interfere with the bad guys, but just to observe them? Maybe get a clue as to how they were making themselves invisible? This, I was sure, would redeem me in Dad's eyes: I could still help him catch the crooks, while staying out of trouble.

Or, to put it another way: It seemed like a good idea at the time.

******************************


I snuck out of my bedroom (nothing easier, for a girl who can walk through walls), and tiptoed my way to Dad's den. There were the paintings he had bought, which he had proudly hung on the walls. Or, at least, they looked just like the paintings: only Dad and I knew that they were imitations, fitted with microchips that would lead the police right to the doors of whoever took them. Remaining invisible, I closed my eyes.

All of a sudden, there was a flash of light, and there they were, all set for criminal mischief. I counted three, one for each painting. I smiled: already, I had learned that the thieves got in and out by teleportation.

The three wore dark, tight-fitting clothing, along with goggles. These, I reasoned, allowed them to see themselves and each other in the course of their criminal enterprise. My smile got wider as they cut the paintings out of the frames. Hope you guys don't drop the soap where you're going, I thought.

Then, I felt cold steel against the back of my head. "One move," said a voice, "and you're dead."

I felt like an idiot as Dad's words came back to me: "What if they can see you, and are armed?" My advantage gone, I made myself visible again, as the man I hadn't looked for tied my wrists. "All set?" he asked his confederates.

"All set," one replied. "Who's your friend?"

"I dunno, some snoop. Did you like what you saw, kid? Wanna see more?"

With that, I was teleported out of Dad's den, and into the thieves' hideout.
11111111111211111112111.title: the thieves take the bait.

111111111112111111121111.content:
Once I had adjusted to the change of surroundings caused by teleportation, my heart sank when I saw Izzy and Mina tied up in the thieves' hideout. Dad was right: I had completely failed at this. I didn't even resist as the three of us were tied together.

"Now hold up just a minute," said one of the thieves. "You promised me that a chunk of the haul from this scheme would be enough for me to retire on. You didn't say anything about kidnapping."

"I hadn't anticipated that they would be up and around in the middle of the night," replied the apparent ringleader. "Besides, think of them as an insurance policy: If all goes well, they can go home once we have what we want."

"And how do these paintings get us that?"

The ringleader rolled his eyes. "It's simple: These paintings were done by an eccentric millionaire. He hid directions to a sizable amount of his fortune in the paintings. We find the directions, we follow them, the money's ours. Understand?"

So Izzy was right. They were after some code in the artwork. And they had no idea that they were leading the police right here, wherever here was.

This news gave me my confidence back. "When I move," I whispered to Izzy and Mina, "you move."

The crooks lined up the paintings, then lit them with a UV light. "There's nothing on three of these," one said.

"A set-up," the ringleader said.

As if on cue, the windows were lit up from outside. "This is the police," said the familiar voice of my father, over a loudspeaker. "We have you surrounded. Give yourselves up."

That was when I made my move. I turned invisible and intangible, then followed Izzy and Mina. At least, I did, until the ringleader spoke again.

"Time for our insurance policy. We use the devisualizer and the teleporter, then leave those girls holding all the evidence. By the time they get it straightened out, if they ever do, we'll be free and clear."

Okay, change of plans: Instead of making good my escape, I had to foil their escape. Heading off the crooks, I picked up something heavy and swung at the first machine I reached.

I must have hit the right spot, because it blew up as soon as I hit it.
111111111112111111121111.title: The Thieves' Plan

1111111111121111111211111.content:
When I opened my eyes, I realized I'd been out cold for a while.

The first thing I did was check myself out. No broken bones, no bleeding. So that was a relief.

I considered closing my eyes again, and they actually fluttered. But then I thought, Maybe I have a concussion. I should wait until I get examined by a doctor.

As I woke up more, I began to hear voices calling my name. "JJ!" "JJ?" I recognized the voices as Dad, Izzy, and Mina.

"Here I am," I said, almost pulling myself up. Something about the ground seemed off somehow, but I couldn't place it yet. "Anybody get the number of that truck?"

"JJ?" Dad said. "Are you okay?"

"Nothing's broken or bleeding."

Dad gave a massive sigh of relief. "You don't know how scared you had me, JJ."

"I'd imagine you were almost as scared as I was. How about the crooks? Where are they?"

"In custody," Izzy said. "One of them already wants to turn state's evidence. Says he was down for stealing, but not kidnapping us, or the plan to frame us."

"Enough of that for now," Dad said. "Turn visible, JJ, I want to have you checked out."

"I was just thinking - wait, what? what do you mean?"

"What do you mean, what do I mean?"

"Why did you ask me to turn visible, when I'm visible now?"

"JJ?" Mina asked. She found something reflective in the rubble and handed it to me. Or, rather, she held it out in the direction she heard my voice coming from.

I took it and looked into it, and I saw that something was wrong.

I could see my hands. Looking down at my body, I saw my body. When I closed my eyes, I saw nothing.

But, when I looked into the reflective surface, I wasn't there.

Then, I remembered how the ground looked off, and I realized why: I wasn't casting a shadow.

I was invisible again, to everyone but me.

And I had no idea how to come back.
1111111111121111111211111.title: I Hit the Devisualizer

11111111111211111112111111.content:
"The mastermind of this operation called that machine a devisualizer," Mina said. "It's how they made themselves invisible for their thefts."

"Presumably," Dad said, "when JJ smashed it, she was hit with whatever caused their invisibility." He turned to me, since I was holding on to him for dear life. "Which is why you're invisible now."

"So all I have to do is wait for it to wear off," I asked, "like it did for them?"

"I... It may not be that simple," he replied. "Remember, most people don't turn invisible themselves, and you do. The ray may have interacted with your body in a way it didn't for them."

I wanted to kick myself. I was invisible, maybe forever, because I was so damn sure that I knew something that my father, the police detective, who had been investigating this case before I even knew it was a case, didn't know. How many ways can one person screw up?

"Mr. Juspeczyk," Izzy said, "they were looking for a fortune that the artist was supposed to have hidden. Once word of that gets out, it'll be open season."

Dad nodded. "We'll take care of that before we release it to the public. Right now, I want to get JJ home. See how everything looks in the morning."

And how did "everything" look in the morning?

Invisible.
11111111111211111112111111.title: The Aftermath

111111111112111111121111111.content:
I don't know if you could call what I had depression. After all, it's not like I could go to a therapist and be diagnosed, is it?

Whatever it was that I had, I no longer wanted to leave my bed.

Mom brought me breakfast, then lunch. When it came time for dinner, she said, "Sweetie, come downstairs and join us."

"Just pretend I'm down there," I replied. "It'll look the same."

About the only time I left my room was to go to the bathroom. Before long, my family could tell which of those two rooms I was in, by which door I slammed shut.

Yeah, I have no doubt I was super fun to share a house with.

Izzy and Mina didn't have it any better. Whenever they came over to try to get me interested in something, I would either tell them to go away, or I would just ignore them.

I didn't count how many days I acted like that, but it was definitely more than two or three.

One day, someone knocked on my door when it wasn't mealtime. "I don't want to talk to anyone!" I yelled at the door.

"Is that so?" asked a familiar voice. "Lucky for me, I'm not just anyone."

I sat up. "Jo Jo?"
111111111112111111121111111.title: Deep Invisible Funk

choices: Getting Back with My Family and Friends
1111111111121111111211111111.content:
My double from another dimension phased through the door. "I came to tell you about my adventure," she said. "But you had an adventure of your own."

"You're talking," I said. "But Dad's recorder isn't in here. How... ?"

"You smashed the devisualizer," she explained. "I smashed the teleporter. It let them travel instantaneously, using the space between dimensions. As a result, dimension-hopping is as easy for me as breathing. It was a trip, in more ways than one. I remember this one dimension, I was in a cell with a naked girl. She told me to get out while I still could, then she started to change." She shivered.

"At least people can still see you," I said. "I'm visible to myself, but not to anyone else."

"You're still visible to me," Jo Jo said, brushing the hair away from my eyes. "You'll find your way back, just like I did. Could you do me a favor before then?"

"What?"

"Take a bath. You're getting pretty rank." She giggled, then vanished.

I took a sniff. She had a point. I got up and went to the bathroom. This time, I closed the door behind me gently.
1111111111121111111211111111.title: Jo Jo

11111111111211111112111111111.content:
A hot shower didn't just kill my bodily funk, it went a long way to pulling me out of my inner funk. Then, I started thinking about how I'd taken my mood out on everyone around me. I cautiously made my way downstairs.

Izzy and Mina were there, along with my family. They were talking, and I don't need to tell you the hot topic. "They've been quiet up there a long time," Frank, Jr., said.

"If Jo Jo can't get through to her," Mom said, "I don't know what to do. We may have to call in an expert, a psychotherapist."

Izzy frowned, and looked in my direction. "What up, Iz?" Mina asked.

"I don't know," she replied. "I have this... feeling. I don't know why, I just know... we're not alone in this room."

Everyone looked around, not sure what to look for.

"I know it's nowhere near enough," I said, startling everybody, "but would saying I'm sorry for being so shitty help?"

"JJ!" Mom cried, jumping up. "Where are you?"

"Standing right next to you."

At that, Mom wrapped her arms around me and hugged the stuffing out of me.

When she finally let me go, I sat down next to Mina. "So, what did I miss, while I had my head up my ass?"

"We followed the map," Dad said. "It wasn't some buried treasure: it was a machine. The caretaker said that our city is at the hub of multiple parallel universes, and the machine keeps them from bumping into each other. Imagine how upset the crooks would be to find that, when they had their hearts set on money."
11111111111211111112111111111.title: Getting Back with My Family and Friends

111111111112111111121111111111.content:
"Seriously," I said, "I want to apologize for the way I've been acting. I'm frustrated with being invisible, but I shouldn't have taken it out on you."

"You know what I do when I'm frustrated?" Mina asked. "I meditate. Wanna try?"

I shrugged. "It can't get me worse results than lying in bed and sulking."

"Okay," she said, getting off the couch. She then sat on the floor and moved her legs into the lotus position. "Let's do this."

Izzy shrugged and joined us.

"Okay," I said, "what's next?"

"Close your eyes," Mina said. "Breathe deeply and evenly. Now, find your focal point."

"I beg your pardon," Izzy said, "but how do I find a focal point if my eyes are closed?"

"Your focal point isn't necessarily a spot or an object," Mina explained. "Focus on something you want."

That part was easy for me. I wanted to be visible.

"Really focus on it," Mina said. "If it has a sound, hear it. If it has a scent, smell it. If it feels a certain way, feel it."

I remembered the last time I lay in the sun, felling the warm rays on my skin.

"JJ!" Frank, Jr., shouted. "I can see you!"

The three of us opened our eyes.

"I can't see her," Izzy said.

"I thought I caught a glimpse of her," Mina said, "but I can't be sure."

"But I saw her," Frank, Jr., said.

"So did I," Mom said. "What was your focal point, JJ?"

"The only thing I could think of that I wanted," I replied. "Being visible."

"I think I see what's going on here," Mina said. "Thanks to the devisualizer, you're naturally invisible now. But, by concentrating, you can make yourself visible."

"But if my concentration is broken, I disappear again."

"Keep trying, JJ. You'll get better at it. Eventually, the level of concentration needed to be visible will almost be second nature to you."

"Nevertheless," Mom said, "I think we'd better stick with homeschooling you for senior year. I don't want the whole school knowing what happens to you when you hear a loud noise."

Mom had a point. Between people dropping books, fire drills, and lockdown drills, my life in school would be a source of constant worry. "Okay, Mom. I only need one explosion to make me start listening to people."
111111111112111111121111111111.title: Trying My Hand at Meditation

1111111111121111111211111111111.content:
Now that I was in a better mood, we spent a few days pounding out a script, and we put out another installment of The J Files. For this one, we gave listeners an update on the Vanishing Artwork case. Well, maybe update isn't the right word. We left out that the crooks had kidnapped three girls (understandable, since we were the girls, and nobody wanted to bring loads of attention my way), and we repeated the official story (read: lie) that the police had found that there was a whole lot of nothing there, since we didn't want to have loads of people looking for it. "My dad says it's like Al Capone's vault," I told my listeners. "I responded by asking what that reference meant. Hashtag millennial humor."

With the recording ended, I said, "Can I get a water bottle?"

Izzy almost handed it right to me.

"Wow, Iz," Mina said, "you're getting really good at locating JJ by the sound of her voice."

"It's not that," Izzy replied. "It's like... I can sense where she is."

"You can see me?" I felt something like hope stirring within me.

"I don't see you, I sense you. You know that feeling you get when someone is staring at you? It's kind of like that."

Mina sighed. "Guess we'll have to wait until you get better at concentrating."

"That's a way off yet," I said. "Not only do loud noises break my concentration, but concentrating for a long time gives me terrible headaches. After an hour, I have to take ibuprofen and lie down in a dark room."
1111111111121111111211111111111.title: My Next Podcast

11111111111211111112111111111111.content:
Our standard celebration for wrapping up and uploading an episode of The J Files was to go out and get bubble tea. We still wanted to do that, but my invisibility meant we had to sit in Mina's car, rather than at a table with an umbrella. "I'm sorry we have to do this, guys," I said. "I know it doesn't have the ambience."

"Don't be silly," Mina replied. "I'd rather sit in my car drinking bubble tea with my best friends than sip chardonnay at Buckingham Palace."

"What kind of friends would we be," Izzy continued, "if we didn't make a little sacrifice?"

"We know that being invisible has been rough for you," Mina said. "You wouldn't have kept yourself cooped up in your bedroom if you were loving every minute of it."

"I'm just guessing," Izzy said, "but I'm thinking that the worst part would be thinking about Grace."

Certainly, picturing Grace not knowing me by photograph hurt.

"I think it's the danger," Mina countered. "One impatient driver while she's trying to cross the street, and... " She let the thought trail off.

"That's the big stuff," I said. "Fear works best when it's smaller, more subtle."

"Like what?"

"There are questions you ask a hundred times a day, that I will never again know the answers to. How's my hair? Do I have something in my teeth? Does my ass look too big in these jeans?"

"Hang on, I've got this," Mina said. "Uh, your hair was blown off in the explosion. Yes, but nobody will notice, thanks to what's on your nose. And, sure, blame the jeans."

We all laughed.
11111111111211111112111111111111.title: Talking About Invisibility

111111111112111111121111111111111.content:
At home, I decided to relax, the way I had before I turned invisible the first time.

Eating was easier for me, since I could now see what my hands were doing, even if nobody else could. Since I didn't have to focus on how to feed myself, I could listen to people again.

After supper, we watched a movie. A pretty funny one. I couldn't stop laughing. Then, I thought of what someone would think of an apparently empty chair laughing, and I laughed at that.

Honestly, if I could go back in time, I might have forgone warning past me about the consequences of getting involved in the Vanishing Artwork case, and concentrated on telling more recent past me to let my family help me feel better. These people aren't my enemies: why did I distance myself from them, even for a few days?

Later that night, I was leaving the bathroom, when I heard Grace's little voice calling out, "Mommy!"

Since Mom didn't rush right in, I figured she was doing something important (possibly involving homeschooling me), so I knocked on Grace's open door. "Mom's a little busy," I said. "Can I help?"

Grace held up one of her favorite books, The Little Engine that Could. "Wead," she said.

"Sure, I'll read to you. Let's get you tucked in."

As soon as Grace was tucked in snugly-bugly, as we put it in our family, I began to read. For the self-important trains who wouldn't help the circus, I imitated the voices of some of the men I'd butted heads with in my podcasting career. For the Little Engine herself, I imitated Grace's voice, letting her hear herself as the heroine.

When we got to the end, Grace looked in my direction and said, "I miss you pwetty." Which, I guess, meant she missed seeing my face.

"I miss it, too, Gracie."

Just then, Mom came in. "Did I hear you calling, Gracie? Is it time for your story?"

"JJ wead it," Grace replied. "You can wead me Saggy Baggy." The Saggy Baggy Elephant was her second-favorite.

I patted Mom on the shoulder, to let her know where I was. "Thank you, JJ," she said.

"No," I replied, "thank you."

As I settled in for bed, I wondered, as if for the first time, what taking care of my own children someday would be like. Maybe it would be like me and Grace just now.

Of course, let's just hope they don't inherit my opacity-challenged status, or I might spend weeks worrying if I diapered the right end.
111111111112111111121111111111111.title: At Home

1111111111121111111211111111111111.content:
The next day, Grace decided to rearrange the playroom, feeling that the table and chairs for her tea parties would look better in a different spot. I knew they weren't heavy, but they might be awkward for her. "Need some help?" I asked.

"I got it," she replied. Then, as she carried the table, I heard her repeat to herself, "I think I can, I think I can, I think I can," just like in the story. I guessed that my idea worked.

The doorbell rang. Checking the peephole, I saw that it was Izzy and Mina, so I opened the door and let them in. It was time to go over ideas for future installments of The J Files.

Normally, these bull sessions take place around the kitchen table. However, when we walked into the kitchen, Mom and Dad were sitting there. "What's going on?" I asked.

"Oh, hi, girls," Dad said. "We've been doing some thinking."

"About what?" Mina asked.

"About what JJ can do for spending money. It's hard to find a job that doesn't require interacting with the public."

"Which is hard to do," Mom added, "when you're invisible."

"She's doing it now," Izzy said.

"What?"

"The podcast," Izzy explained. "Already, she conducts interviews over the phone. We haven't had to meet with anyone since we started."

"And you give us $50 a week each," Mina added. "Either you're paying us to hang out with JJ, or we're making bank."

"The J Files has brought in some money, I'll admit," Dad said. "But it's not quite like you think."

"We could try accepting sponsors," Izzy suggested. "You know, online security, that app where they send you food so you can make a fresh meal at home."

"Or we could start offering merch," Mina suggested. "A lot of people want to show their support for our channel."

"Okay," Dad said, "we'll think about it."

I smiled. When Dad said he would think about something, it generally meant yes. "Okay," I said, "we'll be in my room."

We went upstairs, I checked on Grace (she was satisfied with the redecorating, and was celebrating with a tea party), and we sat on my bed. "Looks like the future of The J Files is set," Mina said.

"How can you tell?" Izzy asked.

"Little things," she replied. " Dad taught me to look for the least little things. I saw your folks nodding at each other while we were talking. I'm pretty sure they're on board."

"I'd say," I said, "the future of The J Files is set, in more ways than one."

"What do you mean?"

"I can come and go as I please, with nobody the wiser. Izzy's got some talent for locating me: who knows where it will lead to? And Mina's a natural detective. Put it all together, and we're the team supreme of amateur crimefighting."

"I don't know," Mina said. "The last time we tried going hands-on, we were kidnapped."

"We were still operating solo," I countered. "I'm talking about really working together, as a team. How about it?"

"I'm in," Izzy said.

Mina shrugged. "Let's give it a shot, see how it goes."
1111111111121111111211111111111111.title: Planning for the Future

11111111111211111112111111111111111.content:
"Time enough for crimefighting later," Izzy said. "Right now, girlfriend, you need to relax, unwind."

"What do you suggest?"

"You used to come over to my place all the time, before you became invisible. Let's get you over there, for old times' sake."

"Think my folks would go for it?"

Izzy gave me a look. "Do I think they'd be on board with getting you out of the house, after a week of you slamming doors?"

"Good point."

******************************


Like Izzy said, my family was okay with me leaving the house in the company of my friends, and we drove to her house.

It wasn't until we were in the door that we remembered Barney.

Barney was her family's Golden Retriever, and I was one of his favorite people. At least, I had been before I turned invisible. I had no idea how I would be greeted by a dog who could smell me, but see empty air.

We didn't have to wait long before we found out. Barney walked into the room and took one look in my direction. Then, he ran up to me, hopped up on his hind legs, and began licking my face. "I guess he missed me," I said, turning my face this way and that to keep his tongue out of my mouth.

"What's up, Barney?" Izzy's mom called out, as she came into the room. "Is Izzy ho - what in the world?" Clearly, she was trying to comprehend the sight of the family dog, on his hind legs, licking what looked like air.

"Hi, Mom," Izzy said.

"What in the world is Barney doing?"

"He's licking my face, Mrs. Kessler," I replied.

"JJ? Where are you hiding?"

"I'm going to touch your left hand, Mrs. Kessler. Don't be alarmed."

I touched her left hand.

She screamed.

Then she fainted.
11111111111211111112111111111111111.title: A Surprise

111111111112111111121111111111111111.content:
Mrs. Kessler came to after a few minutes. I helped her into a seated position. "Are you alright, ma'am?" I asked.

"I'm okay," she said. "But what about you?"

"I'm fine. You know, except for the fact that you can't tell for yourself."

"How did this happen?"

"It's a long story." Still, I tried giving her the short version of a story that included interdimensional travel, crooks looking for a big score, and a hidden device.

On the subject of that device, Mrs. Kessler got to her feet. "You three haven't been playing with that machine, have you?"

"Not me, Mrs. K," I said. "I was feeling sorry for myself for the better part of a week, while the police investigated. Dad told me about the machine, that's how I know."

"None of us have gone near it, Mom," Izzy said. "Wait, you know about it?"

"My grandparents told me about building it. There was a terrible need for it. Imagine walking down the street, and, all of a sudden, everything is on the opposite side of where it should be. Or maybe you meet people who shouldn't exist in reality, like giants, vampires, and witches."

"JJ," Mina said, "isn't that about the time your great-great-aunt went into that parallel universe?"

Mrs. Kessler nodded. "That was how it started."

"Mrs. K," I said, "I went into another dimension, before this last case."

"I have to go," she said. "I've got to check the machine, before hell breaks loose again."
111111111112111111121111111111111111.title: Continue

1111111111121111111211111111111111111.content:
"Can we come along, Mom?" Izzy asked. "If this concerns us, we need to know about it."

"Alright," Mrs. Kessler said. "But don't touch anything, any of you. It's delicate."

Mrs. Kessler drove us out to what looked like a shack in the middle of nowhere. As we approached, we were met by a man dressed head to toe in camouflage, with a long white beard and a semiautomatic rifle. "What's going on?" he asked.

"Hi, Sam, it's Elly," Mrs. Kessler said. "I need to check the machine. Don't worry about the girls, I'll keep them in line."

Sam saluted and let us pass, and we drove up to the shack. "It isn't flashy," Mrs. Kessler said, "but it wasn't made to impress. All it had to do was put an end to the Year of Hell."

The machine certainly didn't look high-tech, but it was still impressive that it was made way back when.

Mrs. Kessler examined the machine, then began adjusting it. Mostly, this involved pulling levers and turning knobs. At one point, it involved tapping the machine at a particular spot with the side of a hammer. Finally, she gave a satisfied grunt and turned to us. "Too much interdimensional travel can knock the machine out of alignment," she said. "When those crooks started their scheme, they probably threw things off enough to dislodge JJ."

"So they're why I turned invisible the first time," I realized. "And why I traveled to Jo Jo's world. And now, she can travel to different dimensions easily. She hit the teleporter instead of the devisualizer."

"Next time you see her," Mrs. Kessler said, "warn her not to do too much dimension-hopping. It was only enough to shake things up for you, but too much can open us up for nightmarish other worlds. I don't know about you, but I prefer living in a world where vampires, werewolves, giants, shrinking, mysterious pregnancies, and worse are just make-believe."

"They'd make for pretty interesting installments of The J Files, though," Izzy said.

"Izzy, my girl, there is a reason why the Chinese considered 'May you live in interesting times' to be a terrible curse."
1111111111121111111211111111111111111.title: The Machine

11111111111211111112111111111111111111.content:
When I got home, Jo Jo was there to greet me. "What've you been up to, JJ?" she asked.

"Been learning about interdimensional travel," I replied, "and the machine that keeps the universes separate." I put my hand on her shoulder. "I'm afraid I have to ask you to take fewer dimension-hopping jaunts."

She nodded. "I got the same lecture in my world. But hey, I can still drop in and see you on birthdays and holidays, right?"

I smiled. "Those should be far enough apart to minimize disruption. Guess I'll see you then."

"Count on it, like I'm counting on you to find the way back to visibility."

"One day at a time. Take care of yourself."

"Don't I always?" With that, Jo Jo was gone.
11111111111211111112111111111111111111.title: At Home

choices: I wake up in the hospital.
1111111111121111111211112.content:
The second the cinder block hit the teleporter, it exploded and I was immersed in a blinding light that forced me to close my eyes. I felt a rush of air and nearly screamed as my ears popped from a sudden change in air pressure just before I passed out.... "Am I dead....?" Feeling and seeing nothing, I thought. "Where am I...?"

"Not where you belong, colleen." Forcefully, a female voice said.

My eyes adjusted to the dim light and I found myself in the bed chambers of a tall woman with long, flowing red hair in an old-fashioned nightgown. "Um,... excuse the trespass, I do not know how I got here..."

"I suggest you find a way to be gone, and soon." Courtly, the woman said. "Unless, of course, you wish to die here."

She then smiled, revealing two pearly white fangs. I let out a short screech of fear before the bright flash came again. A knock came to the door and a strong male voice spoke, "We heard a scream, mistress Finola..."

"It is nothing to be concerned about, Mr. Sutherland." The woman, Finola, replied. "It was just a young lost Puca."

The light dimmed again and I found myself in a small village somewhere,... only, strangely, the trees were artificial. I looked around and gasped upon seeing that the village was on top of a giant table somewhere! "Where am I now...?!"

"Um... hi, there." An uncertain voice said.

I spun around to find a teenage girl and boy staring at me from the sidewalk. "Are you new to our community?" Curious, the girl asked. "Mr. Grey did not mention anyone else getting shrunk by the Nymph comet fragments."

"Shrunk...?" Pale, I asked.

The boy and girl turned to each other, worried. "You don't know...?"

I shook my head, but before I could utter a word, the bright light came again. The boy and girl jumped, seeing me vanish. "Um,... let's not tell Staci about that one, Tommy."

"I'm with you, sis." Unnerved, the boy, Tommy said. "That was just too weird."

The light faded one more time and I felt myself falling. I let out a terrified scream just before a huge hand had caught me. I looked up and nearly screamed again as I found myself in the gentle grip of a fifty foot woman! "Easy there, I have you." Gently, she said. "You are safe."

"Help me!" Terrified, I screamed. "I can't..." I screamed again as the bright light took me once more. The girl looked all around, startled, as I had vanished from sight. She turned to a policewoman, who could only shrug. "There are tales of ghosts reliving their last moments here on Old Town Road, Summer." Sadly, she said. "You may have just witnessed one."

When the light dimmed again, I found myself facing Dad, and I immediately embraced him, crying my eyes out. "Please don't let me vanish again!" Wailing, I begged. "I'm sorry... I'm sorry... I know you are the real detective!"

Dad returned my embrace, but surprised me upon saying, "Jay Jay... what happened to turn you into a girl?!"

Stunned, I pushed myself away from Dad, only to find that the man was not my father, as he had Mom's hair and eyes! Terrified, I looked around to find that my friends were now boys. "Izzy... Mina...?"

The two looked at each other and shook their heads. "I'm Ozzy and this is Mark."

Tears fell as my mind reeled to take it all in, but it was too much, and I fainted...
1111111111121111111211112.title: A frightful journey.

11111111111211111112111121.content:
I woke up what felt like hours later to find myself in my bedroom, or what seemed to be my bedroom. I looked around to find Jo Jo sitting in a chair next to the bed. She smiled upon catching my eye. "Welcome back to the world of the living." Calmly, she said. "You gave both our fathers quite a scare."

"Am I in my world or yours?" Wincing, I asked.

"You are in your world." Softly, Jo Jo replied. "Only by destroying that teleporter, you really opened a huge can of worms for you."

"What do you mean?" Worried, I asked.

"That so-called treasure map was the location of some weird dampening device." Serious, Jo Jo explained. "Apparently, this little city rests on a trans-dimensional hub, and that device keeps people from other realities from visiting, and us visiting them."

"Only the strange machine the thieves had allowed them to move through this hub." Wincing, I said. "I see..."

"They could not naturally become invisible like you or I, hence the machines." with a sense of sadness, Jo Jo said. "You destroyed the teleporter, completing your ability to move through the hub. Me, I destroyed the invisibility machine."

"What happened...?" Worried, I asked.

Jo Jo sighed then turned invisible. "Unless I concentrate, I am permanently invisible." Sadly, she replied. "I'm sure that, with time, it will become second nature, but that won't be for a while."

I sighed. "At least you are not jumping..." Softly, I started.

Jo Jo hushed me to be quiet before becoming visible. "Don't think of it!" Scolding, she hissed. "My team and I believe 'what if' thoughts trigger the jump, as that is pretty much what runs through one's mind when their life flashes before their eyes."

"That is going to be hard to control." Wincing, I said.

Jo Jo sighed. "Tell me about it." Frustrated, she said. "I suggest you and I join forces for now, to figure this hub out, and maybe help ourselves in the process."

I nodded. "It sounds like a plan to me."
11111111111211111112111121.title: The Hub is revealed.

111111111112111111121111211.content:
Jo Jo nodded, then gave a sharp whistle. To my surprise, another version of Izzy and Mina appeared inside my office. At that same time, my world's Izzy and Mina walked in and froze, seeing doubles of all three of us. "What...?!" We all blurted out.

"In my world, Mom managed to repair the two machines." Serious, Jo Jo said. "Only we still need to work fast, before what happened to us both becomes permanent."

The two Izzys walked up to each other, perplexed. "You are me..." In unison, they said. They then smiled and said in unison, "Jinx... you owe me a soda..."

Both Jo Jo and I sighed and said in unison, "Izzy..."

With everyone calmed down, we began to compare notes on what we were able to dig up on the device keeping the alternate universes apart from each other. Every now and then, Jo Jo would vanish, but my Izzy seemed to be able to see her clearly, as could my version of Mina. "That's interesting..." Thoughtful, Jo Jo said. "No one in my world can see me while I'm invisible, but your team can."

"They can't see me while I'm invisible,... can they?" Wincing, i asked.

"Let's try it." Serious, Jo Jo said. "Turn invisible, but only focus on that."

I nodded and turned invisible, though it was hard not to think of any what ifs. Once I had managed it, I turned to both teams and asked, "Well, can you see me?"

"I can." Jo Jo's Izzy said.

"As can I." Serious, Jo Jo's Mina added.

Both my Izzy and Mina shrugged, looking around. "We can't..." Softly, they said.

"That is so weird." Wincing, I said. I became visible again. "What do you think that means for any of us?"

"Nothing,... I hope." Darkly, Jo Jo said.

"I know that look." Worried, I said. "I've seen it in the mirror. What are you fearing?"

Jo Jo sighed. "That the device is beginning to fail..."
111111111112111111121111211.title: Researching the hub.

1111111111121111111211112112.content:
